message: http://mac.github.com -- this is definitely a step in the right direction.
Though, I am having some trouble on Lion. Any place I can file some issues?
anyway, just something to keep in mind
@hoxworth same here, though, they are stashed away and safe.
Only this programmed with objetive-c?
I checked to see if they were stashed and couldn't find them on my end, but I might have run a few other operations that cleared the stash

I think the client is cool, but I ran into a slight issue. I downloaded it to try it out on a local repo, and it somehow clobbered local changes I hadn't committed yet. I should be more careful, sure, but I'm afraid to do much in the UI when my Git repo is in an unclean state.
@jyr: Yes, it's all Objective-C & C
Thanks guys
I think it's an awesome start.  @kneath where can we file issues/request?  Like "don't auto-add" untracked files that aren't in the gitignore ?
Send anything to support@github.com
We might be a little slow since we're getting a little flooded and busy fixing crashes, but it's the best place for stuff like that

Oh, a native application. We've grown unused to that kind of dedication. The GUI looks intelligent and quite intuitive. Feels like it has a message to me: it wants to teach me its own way of using Git and GitHub. I raise my glass to you, folks.
Serious quality.

To be honest, I won't use it until some things are changed. For a Git client it's too restricted, too high-level. For a GitHub client it has too few special features, like forking, pull-requests, issues etc. I'd really love to see the client evolve in both directions. But only one would be cool too. Until that happens I'll use GitX.
Don't get me wrong. The client looks nice and it's definitely a start. Keep up the good work.
I've really liked ... using it already!  The button "clone in mac" is a good catch either.
Kneath, what ui libraries did you use, BWToolkit, but what else?
@kneath when we try to commit with no message, there is a typo in the warning (summory instead of summary)
Thanks, good catch
@dustineichler: We're not using BWToolkit. We're using Chameleon (UIKit), Sparkle, FeedbackReporter, and ObjectiveGit
congratulations on the mac client! I think it's a great way to help designers start using GitHub...
The client really needs a --graph view of history and branches. Not being able to see where branches are relative to eachother keeps me using the cli and gitx.
Synchronized less: https://skitch.com/werehamster/fg1g8/github
